metadata.bible_text: Matthew 25:1-13 (Wise and Foolish Virgins); Romans 8:38-39; Revelation 12:7-9, 11:15
metadata.sermon_start_end: Some of you have been curious about the hymns I would choose on this night when the subject, hell, has been so widely advertised. The fact is that I have never had an easier time picking hymns. All I had to do was look through the Advent section [...] Then the seventh angel blew his trumpet, and there were loud voices in heaven, saying, “The kingdoms of this world have become the Kingdom of our Lord and of his Christ, and he shall reign for ever and ever.” (Rev. 12:7, 9; 11:15) Amen. Hallelujah!

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon fails Dekker's primary formal requirement. It is a thematic speech about 'Hell' rather than an exposition of a specific pericope. The Matthew 25 text is introduced very late and treated as an illustration for the theme, rather than the source of the message. It lacks the specificity of what can be found 'nowhere else' in a single text.
quotes: Our Gospel lesson tonight was one of the classic lessons for Advent, the story of the wise and foolish virgins.
A speech about 'the gospel', 'the power of God'... is not a sermon [Thesis 1.3]
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Select one passage (e.g., Matthew 25:1-13) and derive the entire movement of the sermon from its specific logic rather than using it as a late-stage proof text for a thematic study.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: Exegesis is largely absent. The preacher engages with cultural history (Dante, Milton, Alice Turner) and modern journalism rather than the Hebrew or Greek context or the specific theology of the biblical authors. The biblical quotes are used as 'repetitive rhetoric' rather than being expounded.
quotes: I am not very interested in the concept of hell as a place of unceasing fiery torture, which I believe to be extrabiblical.
the descriptions of hell in Matthew, Mark, and Luke are 'colorfully hyperbolic repetitive rhetoric' used to make a point.
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Engage with the specific linguistic and historical context of 'Gehenna' or the 'outer darkness' in Matthew to explain what the text meant to its original audience.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: This is the sermon's strongest point. The preacher connects the concept of 'hell' to very concrete contemporary horrors (Auschwitz, El Salvador, tobacco industry lies, suicide). It avoids 'general truths' by naming specific entities and events.
quotes: Auschwitz was not just the absence of good. Pol Pot’s genocide in Cambodia was not just the absence of good.
a tobacco company executive, for instance, will testify with a straight face, 'To my knowledge, it’s not been proven that cigarette smoking causes cancer.'
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Ensure the application flows from the text's specific demands rather than from a general sociological observation of evil.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: Because there is little formal exposition of a text, the 'interwoveness' is actually a blend of cultural commentary and application. The hearer is not drawn into the Bible passage, but into the preacher's thematic argument.
quotes: I believe what I am going to say is compatible with the New Testament and with the facts of life in this world.
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Structure the sermon so that the contemporary examples (tobacco, genocide) serve to unlock the specific meaning of the biblical imagery.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: The sermon deals extensively with 'misery' (radical evil) and 'redemption' (Christ vanquishing the devil). It touches on 'gratitude' through the wedding illustration. It successfully avoids a purely objective Christocentrism by grounding the sermon in human experience.
quotes: We must believe in hell because there is no other way to take seriously the nature and scale of evil in the world.
We were two sinners rejoicing in the same salvation, the same deliverance.
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Deepen the 'gratitude' aspect by showing how the specific text (the oil in the lamps) relates to the life of the believer.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The sermon acknowledges the 'two ways' through the door being shut in Matthew 25, but the preacher's dismissal of 'eternal fire' as hyperbolic risks softening the 'ultimate possibilities' Dekker emphasizes. However, the 'temporal loss' (suicide, societal decay) is handled with the required seriousness.
quotes: The other five have the door shut in their faces, and hear these terrible words: 'Truly, I say to you, I do not know you.'
A person can be lost in time and in eternity. [Thesis 6]
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Avoid dismissing biblical imagery as 'hyperbolic' too quickly; instead, explore the 'hideous strength' of being lost as a real possibility for the hearer.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Christ is indeed the telos. The sermon concludes with the victory of Christ and the assurance of Romans 8. The doctrine of the two natures is implied in the discussion of God entering the 'fleshly abode' to fight the devil.
quotes: the meaning of Christmas is that God has entered the lists against the Prince of Darkness... Satan has met his master.
The kingdoms of this world have become the Kingdom of our Lord and of his Christ.
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Explicitly link the person of Christ to the specific text's demands (e.g., Christ as the Bridegroom) rather than a general cosmic victor.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 1850 words, the sermon likely clocks in just under the 20-minute threshold required by Dekker for 'depth.' It risks being a series of anecdotes rather than a sustained 'broad' exploration of a text.
quotes: A sermon that lasts less than 20 minutes cannot be a sermon. [Thesis 8]
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Increase the exegetical weight to extend the duration and provide the 'breadth' needed for theological depth.

overall_assessment.summary: The text falls short of Dekker's definition of a sermon primarily because it is a thematic topical address rather than an exposition of a specific Bible passage. It relies heavily on cultural references (literature, music, news) at the expense of rigorous biblical exegesis. However, it excels in concrete application and takes the reality of human misery and radical evil seriously, avoiding the 'sentimental' trap Dekker warns against.
strengths: Concrete application that names specific societal and personal evils.
Strong sense of the 'Three Parts' (misery and redemption are palpable).
Clear Christological telos in the conclusion.
weaknesses: Lack of a single, central Bible passage (Thesis 1.3).
Absence of original language exegesis or historical-critical depth (Thesis 2).
Duration likely falls below the 20-minute minimum for 'depth' (Thesis 8).
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: According to Dekker's strict formal criteria, this is an 'adequate speech' or 'thematic meditation,' but it is not a 'sermon' because it does not recreate a specific Bible passage into a new, current word. It is a bicycle mechanic who has described the history of the wheel but failed to mount it to the frame of the text.
